newsitem.title: USA: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- unchanged, but firmer tone.
newsitem.headline: U.S. MUNICIPAL FOCUS -- unchanged, but firmer tone.

text.p: U.S. municipal bond prices were unchanged at the close on Monday, recovering a firmer tone in late trading after showing weakness at midday.
Traders said activity levels were extremely light all day, and moved in a narrow range.
U.S. Treasury prices were also mostly unchanged, after sagging at midday. The government long bond was up 1/32 at 96-27/32 to yield 6.87 percent.
With little to provide direction Monday, the focus turned early to supply and data coming later this week.
The Treasury is set to sell $17 billion of 3-year notes Tuesday and $12 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday.
Supply in the municipal market this week is expected to total $4.1 billion in 102 sales.
Sales for Tuesday are expected to total $1.7 billion in 44 sales, according to Reuters Municipal Bond Information Group.
Negotiated offerings total $1.5 billion in 20 sales, with a $486 million San Antonio, Texas, deal through PaineWebber Inc. topping the list.
On the competitive side, 24 sales totaling $194 million are on the Tuesday schedule. A $53 million Hamilton County, Tenn., deal at 1100 EDT is the largest.

In the muni secondary Monday, Dade County, Fla., water and sewer FGIC 5-1/4s of 2026 were were bid at 5.72 percent, down one basis point from Friday. Port Authority of New York and New Jersey JFK International Air Terminal MBIA 5.75s of 2022 were unchanged at 5.94 percent.
June municipal bond futures closed up 6/32 at 115-4/32, while June Treasury bonds edged up 4/32 to 110-5/32. The MOB spread narrowed to 159 ticks from 161 at the close Friday.
Tuesday's data releases include factory orders for March. Expectations among economists surveyed by Reuters are for a 1.5 percent drop, compared to a 0.8 percent increase the previous month.
